title-group.article-title: Mechanical and tactile properties of plain knitted fabrics produced from rayon Vortex yarns

article-meta.aff: Department of Advanced Fibro Science, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Sachiko Sukigara, Kyoto Institute of Technology, Matsugasaki, Sakyo-ku, Kyoto 606-8585, Japan. Email: sukigara@kit.ac.jp

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: We investigated and compared rayon Vortex, ring-spun, and open-end spun yarns, and plain knitted fabrics produced from these yarns. Yarn tensile, compression, bending, and torsion tests were conducted, and differences between spinning systems were observed for bending and torsion properties. Evaluation by hand indicated that the Vortex fabric was much smoother than fabric made from open-end yarn, but less smooth than the fabric produced from ring-spun yarn. Fabric smoothness was related to both its air resistance and the hairiness of its yarn. Fabric air resistance is found to be a useful index to describe the tactile properties of knitted fabrics.

body.p: Various factors influence fabric hand, including the structure, surface, and mechanical properties of the fabric and the yarn from which it is made. Even if the same fiber is used, different spinning systems produce different yarn structures with different properties, reflected in the mechanical properties of the fabrics produced from those yarns.

The Murata Vortex Spinner (MVS; Murata Machinery Co., Ltd, Japan) produces yarn with a structure different from ring-spun yarn, and does so at very high speeds. In the Vortex spinning system, one tip of a fiber is pushed to the center of the yarn by compressed air, and then the other tip forms an outer layer that wraps around the central fiber. The effects of process parameters for yarn structure1–3 and the tensile property1,4,5 for this spinning system have been studied. Initially, cotton fibers were used, but now the MVS also produces rayon, polyester, wool, and core-spun yarns containing spandex.6 A well-known advantage of Vortex yarn is that it is less hairy than conventional ring-spun and open-end spun yarns, resulting in a lower pilling tendency, which makes it particularly suitable for knitted fabrics.7,8 The dimensional and mechanical properties of woven fabric made from Vortex yarn have also been reported.9,10 However, the tactile properties of fabrics, especially the smoothness of knitted fabrics from Vortex yarns, have not attracted much attention. Consumers can consistently evaluate smoothness, however, making it an important factor influencing preference in, for example, underwear garments.

In this study, we first investigated the surface and cross-sectional structure of Vortex yarns using a stereoscope. We next examined the mechanical properties of various yarns, including tensile, compression, bending, and torsion strength properties. Tensile strength and elongation of yarn are the most common evaluation parameters for yarn producers. When consumers evaluate garments by hand, however, they cannot directly evaluate yarn strength and elongation. When considering how consumers evaluate fabrics, therefore, other parameters need to be considered. Kawabata and Niwa11 developed the Kawabata Evaluation System (KES), which utilizes the mechanical properties of fabrics to estimate fabric hand. They also developed a yarn measurement system,12,13 and described the non-linear mechanics of yarn for woven and knitted materials.14

We evaluated the mechanical properties of fabrics made from these yarns using the KES. We conducted fabric tactile evaluation to determine the relationship between a fabric’s surface smoothness and the mechanical properties of its yarn. We hope to establish useful parameters for relating the mechanical properties of Vortex yarn to fabric tactile properties that could be used for yarn and fabric quality control.

sec.title: Yarn and fabric samples
sec.p:
Plain, weft-knitted fabrics were made from three kinds of rayon Vortex yarns (Ry1, Ry2, and Ry3 in Table 1), ring-spun yarns (Ry4), and open-end spun yarns (Ry5), all at the same 197 dtex yarn count. Vortex yarns Ry1, Ry2, and Ry3 were produced by a Vortex-861 machine using three different nozzles: ECO, Crown, and Crown-synthetic. ECO is the standard nozzle for the Vortex-861. The Crown nozzle was specially developed for cotton spinning, with the goal of improving fabric hand and reduction of fiber waste. The Crown-synthetic nozzle is a Crown nozzle modified for synthetic fibers. All yarns were made of rayon fibers at 1.2 dtex and 38 mm length. Fabrics made from these yarn samples were produced with the same knitting machine and finishing to obtain identical fabric structures. Descriptions of fabric samples are listed in Table 2. Table 1.
Rayon yarn properties
Sample Spinning system Average breaking strength Average breaking elongation Hairinessa
Vortex nozzleb (N/tex) CV% (%) CV%
Ry1 Vortex ECO 0.140 8.6 11.11 9.6 4.06
Ry2 Crown 0.131 8.4 10.09 10.5 4.79
Ry3 Crown-synthetic 0.135 7.9 10.47 8.5 4.35
Ry4 Ring 0.153 8.3 11.55 10.6 5.45
Ry5 Open-end 0.117 9.1 9.96 10.9 4.17
a
Uster hairiness index: UT5. b
ECO is the standard nozzle for Vorets-861. Crown is specially developed for cotton spinning aimed at improving fabric hand. Crown-synthetic is modified Crown for synthetic fibers.
Table 2.
Description of plain knitted fabrics
Fabric code Yarn Wales/cm (W) Course/cm (C) Stitch density W × C (/cm2) Weight (g/m2) Thicknessa (mm)
R1 Ry1 14.0 18.0 252.0 151.6 0.91
R2 Ry2 14.0 17.8 249.2 148.6 0.92
R3 Ry3 14.4 17.7 254.9 150.3 0.87
R4 Ry4 14.5 18.5 268.2 156.6 0.93
R5 Ry5 14.5 18.5 268.3 158.5 0.88
a
Thickness at 49 Pa.

sec.title: Observation of the yarn surface
sec.p:
The yarn surface was observed using a stereoscope (Olympus SZ-PT stereomicroscope with a Leica DFC 280 digital camera), and the parameters were measured using the image analysis function in the Adobe Photoshop CS3 graphics software package. For each type of yarn, at least 50 digitized images were obtained from among at least 75 randomly chosen locations. We measured the observable yarn structural parameters, which included the wrapping angle, the area covered with wrapper fibers, and the turns per centimeter on the yarn surface (Figure 1). The twist factor was calculated using Equation (1): (1)twist factor=tcount Figure 1.
Yarn surface observations of (a) wrapping angle θ and (b) area covered with wrapper fibers.
Here, t is the turns per centimeter on the yarn surface, and Count is the yarn’s tex number.

sec.title: Observation of the yarn cross-section
sec.p: Cross-sections along the yarn diameter and in the longitudinal direction were observed to investigate the filling ratio and distribution of fibers in a rayon yarn. Prior to obtaining the cross-sections, the yarn samples were mounted in a frame to keep them straight, and were embedded with epoxide resin. Each sample was then sliced in two directions by using a rotary microtome, perpendicular to the yarn axis every 50 µm and at 20 µm intervals along the yarn axis from surface to center. The cross-sectional samples were observed using a Nikon Eclipse E600 POL optical microscope with an Olympus E-300 digital camera.

From images of the cross-sections perpendicular to the yarn axis, the ratio of the cross-sectional area of fibers in the whole yarn cross-sectional area (filling ratio) was calculated using Adobe Photoshop CS3.

sec.title: Measurement of yarn and fabric mechanical properties
sec.p:
The mechanical properties of the yarns and fabrics were measured by using the KES-F system (Kato Tech. Co., Ltd, Japan). Yarn tensile, compression, bending, and torsion tests13 were conducted under the measurement conditions listed in Table 3. These conditions were chosen to measure the appropriate yarn properties related to tactile fabric characteristics.12 For the yarn compression test, a flat contactor (5 mm × 0.2 mm, yarn contact area 0.04 mm2) was attached to a compression tester (KES-G5s, Kato Tech. Co., Ltd, Japan). The contactor compressed the perpendicular yarn axis (see Figure 2) at a compression speed of 0.01 mm/s to a maximum pressure of 2.5 × 106 Pa. The torsion tests were carried out on the KES-SKT-1 tester. Figure 3 shows examples of results curves with values of torsion rigidity, T, and hysteresis, 2HT5 and 2HT. Figure 2.
Yarn sample compression test.
Figure 3.
Yarn torque-angle curve. T: torsion rigidity; 2HT: hysteresis at ± 1 torsion angle; 2HT5: hysteresis at ± 3 torsion angle.
Table 3.
Yarn measurement condition
Properties Measurement condition Parameter
Tensile Maximum load 1.5 × 102 N/tex LT, WT
Elongation speed 0.01 mm/s RT, EM
Sample length 30 mm
Compression Maximum pressure 2.5 MPa LC, WC
Compression speed 0.01 mm/s RC
Contactor size 5 mm width × 0.2 mm thickness dT (thickness change)
Contact area 0.04 mm2
Bending Maximum curvature ±2.5 cm–1 B (bending rigidity)
Bending speed 0.5 cm–1/s 2HB (bending hysteresis)
Torsion Maximum torsional rotation number 6π T, 2HT, 2HT5
Rotation speed 180 deg/s
The parameters for the properties are defined in Appendix 2 and in Figure 3.

Fabric tensile strength, shear, and surface properties were measured according to the knitted measurement condition.15 These modified standards (in Appendix 1) have been used for determining the fabric hand for specially knitted fabrics. Values of air resistance were determined on the KESF-8AP tester.

sec.title: Sensory test
sec.p:
Variations in the mechanical parameters of knitted fabrics can result in detectable differences in sensory assessment.16 Sensory tests were carried out to examine whether the differences that resulted from various yarn structures could be detected. Five knitted fabrics were evaluated by 48 university students (16 men and 32 women). Scheffé’s method of paired comparison, a modification of the method of Nakaya,17 was used to evaluate the degree of smoothness and extensibility on a five-point scale (−2 to 2). Evaluators were instructed to judge the smoothness and extensibility (mechanical deformation) as follows: the fabric was folded in half with thumb and forefinger, then fingers were moved gently along the surface to determine smoothness, and then the fabric was gently pulled in a sidelong direction to determine extensibility (Figure 4). Sensory tests were carried out in the laboratory at 20.5℃ and 52.2% relative humidity (RH), so that the hands of the evaluators would not get wet with sweat. Figure 4.
Tactile evaluation of fabric.

sec.title: Observation of yarn surface and cross-section
sec.p:
Table 4 lists, for each of the four samples, the wrapping angle, the ratio of the area covered with wrapper fibers on the yarn surface, and the twist factor. Table 4.
Characteristic of yarn structure
Sample Wrapping angle Ratio of area covered with wrapper fibers on yarn surface Twist factor
Mean (deg.) CV.% Mean (%) CV (%)
Ry1 24.7 5.9 63.6 6.0 28.94
Ry2 20.0 3.4 61.0 4.94 20.74
Ry3 22.3 4.6 63.0 13.45 24.70
Ry4 17.3 14.1 100 – 20.47

Figure 5 shows photographs of the cross-section along the axis for rayon Vortex yarn (Ry3). Wrapping fibers are seen in panels (1)–(4) and also (10)–(12). Panels (6) and (7) show cross-sections near the yarn sample center. This area was compared with samples from three Vortex yarns and a ring-spun yarn, as shown in Figure 6. These photographs show that the center fibers have almost no twists, but vary in slow waves along the yarn axis. These waves seem to be larger for the Vortex yarn samples Ry1 and Ry3 than for Ry2. The twist factors of Ry1 and Ry3 are larger than Ry2, indicating that the wrapping angle influenced the wave of the center part of the fibers. Figure 7 shows the cross-section cut perpendicular to the yarn axis for four yarn samples. The ratio of wrapping fibers to center fibers is difficult to determine. Figure 5.
Yarn cross-section along the yarn axis from the surface to the center at 20 µm intervals.
Figure 6.
Center part of yarn cross-section along the yarn axis. (a) Ry1: twist factor = 28.9; (b) Ry2: twist factor = 20.7; (c) Ry3: twist factor = 24.7; (d) Ry4: twist factor = 20.5.
Figure 7.
Yarn cross-section.

The filling ratios of Vortex yarns were 79 ± 3.2% for Ry1, 56.0 ± 5.1% for Ry2, and 67.8 ± 4.2% for Ry3. This ratio increased with the increase of the twist factor, and thus the fiber density of Ry1 was largest. The filling ratio of the ring-spun yarn (Ry4) was 64 ± 4.4% and the open-end yarn (Ry5) was 60 ± 4.0%.

sec.title: Interrelation of yarn, fabric, and fabric hand
Yarn and fabric properties
sec.p:
The average mechanical properties of three rayon Vortex yarns were compared with those of ring-spun yarn. Figure 8 shows the percentage as follows: V = (Xv − Xr)/Xr × 100, where Xv is the value for Vortex yarn and Xr is the value for ring yarn, for all parameters and samples. The parameters for the properties are defined in Appendix 2. In this figure, the V = 0 line indicates that the value is identical to that of a ring-spun yarn. It is clear that bending rigidity and bending hysteresis for the Vortex yarns were much higher than those of the ring-spun yarn. The Vortex yarns (Ry1, Ry2, and Ry3) were slightly more compressed than the ring-spun yarns when the yarns were made of the same fiber type and had the same yarn count. Compared with ring-spun yarn, the Vortex yarns showed a tendency to be soft in compression but stiff in bending deformation. Figure 8.
Yarn mechanical properties: V = (Xv – Xr)/Xr × 100, where Xv is the value for Vortex yarn and Xr is the value for ring yarn. The parameters for the properties are defined in Appendix 2.

In Figure 9, the linearity of the compression thickness curve (LC) is plotted against the filling ratio for five yarn samples. As shown in Figure 7, yarn with a higher fiber density (Vortex yarn Ry1) was compressed linearly and showed higher values of LC. Yarns having a smaller wrapping angle, such as Ry2, showed a smaller filling ratio, that is, more vacancies existed among the fibers, and as a result LC was smaller. Figure 9.
Relationship between the linearity of the compression thickness curve (LC) and the yarn filling ratio.

The differences in torsional rigidity obtained from over-adding twisting direction and hysteresis (2HT, 2HT5) was observed among the samples. The torsional rigidity of the Vortex yarns was smaller than that of Ry4, but the hysteresis of the Vortex yarns was larger. Because of the Vortex structure, one tip of a fiber is pushed to the center of the yarn by compressed air, and then the other tip forms an outer layer that wraps around the central fiber. During the untwisting deformation, more fiber migration can occur than in ring-spun yarn.

Average values of wale and course directions for each parameter are used to calculate V (%), the ratio against fabric R4 made from ring-spun yarns. Values are plotted in Figure 10. Bending rigidity of Vortex yarns is larger than that for ring-spun yarns. However, bending rigidity values of all fabrics shown in Table 5 are low, so differences between the yarns are not clearly reflected in the fabric bending properties. Differences observed in the fabric compression energy (WC) may be the constituent loop deformation. However, the relationship between fabric mechanical properties and yarn properties was not clear for these Vortex samples. We therefore considered parameters that could be related to the yarn hairiness. Figure 10.
Fabric mechanical properties: V = (Xv−Xr)/Xr × 100, where Xv is the value for vortex fabrics and Xr is the value for the ring yarn fabric. The parameters for the properties are defined in Appendix 2.

Figure 11 shows the relationship between yarn hairiness and the air resistance of the fabrics. Increased yarn hairiness led to increased air resistance, which is a useful parameter. Figure 11.
Plots of air resistance of fabrics against yarn hairiness.

sec.title: Fabric hand
sec.p:
All subjective values were statistically analyzed. The main effects of smoothness and extensibility were all significant at the 1% level. The average estimate of the evaluator preference was calculated according to a standard paired-comparison test.16 There was a significant difference of smoothness between the samples (Figure 12). According to the evaluators’ assessment for smoothness, the fabric R4 from ring-spun yarn Ry4 had the smoothest surface, and fabric R5 made from open-end yarn (Ry5) had the roughest surface among the samples. This ordering had a confidence level of 99%, so subjects detected differences in the smoothness. Vortex yarn fabrics R1, R2, and R3 were between fabric R5 and fabric R4. Fabric R4 was judged to be the most extensible, and fabric R5 was the least extensible. Differences of extensibility between R1 and R2, and between R3 and R4, were not significant at the 1% level. No relationship between extension at maximum load (EM) and subjective extensibility was clearly observed. On the other hand, the fabric having the lowest shear rigidity (G) was perceived to be more extensible in the human sensory test. This may be due to the manner in which the test was performed, because evaluators did not extend fabrics along the wale and course directions. Figure 12.
Estimate of the judge’s preference for “smoothness” and “extensibility”. The symbol * indicates 1% significance level.

Figures 13 and 14, respectively, compare the mean deviations of the mean coefficient of friction (MMD) and air resistance with the results of the sensory test for smoothness. Fabrics with smaller MMD were perceived to be smoother in the human sensory test. Also, air resistance increased with increasing smoothness, and Figure 10 shows that yarn hairiness was also reflected in the fabric air resistance. It seems that the movement of fabric hair on the surface is perceived as smoothness. In Figure 15, the smoothness of the sensory test is plotted against the yarn hairiness index values. Fabric hair on the surface also contributed to tactile smoothness. Fabrics having lower shear rigidity (G) were also perceived to be smoother. Some fabric deformation occurred when the evaluators’ fingers moved on the fabric surface due to the way they were told to judge smoothness; therefore, they may have taken account of the fabric shear resistance. Figure 13.
Plots of mean deviation of mean coefficient of friction (MMD) against “smoothness” value obtained from the sensory test.
Figure 14.
Plots of air resistance against “smoothness” value obtained from the sensory test.
Figure 15.
Plots of hairiness against “smoothness” value obtained from the sensory test.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Vortex spinning systems produce yarn structures different from ring and open-end spinning. To characterize Vortex yarns, we investigated wrapping angles and the ratio of the surface area covered by the wrapping fibers as they related to yarn and fabric surfaces and mechanical properties. Increased wrapping angle resulted in a decrease in yarn hairiness. Photographs of the cross-section along the axis of rayon Vortex yarn show that the center fibers have almost no twists, but vary in slow waves along the yarn axis. These waves seem to be larger for Vortex yarn samples with larger twist factors; thus, the wrapping angle influenced the wave of the center part of the fibers. Vortex yarns showed a tendency to be soft in compression but stiff in bending deformation, as compared with ring-spun yarn. However, this difference in the bending rigidity of yarns was not clearly observed in the fabric bending rigidity among the samples. On the other hand, it was clear that increased yarn hairiness leads to increased fabric air resistance. In the hand evaluation of fabrics, fabrics produced from rayon Vortex yarns were judged less smooth than fabrics of ring-spun yarns. Evaluators judged fabrics with greater hairiness as smoother because of the soft rayon fiber. This study found the air resistance of the fabric to be an index parameter that describes yarn hairiness and fabric smoothness. Further experiments for various Vortex yarns and fabrics are required to find the range of values obtained from index parameters for quality control.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
